scene-body.stagedir: Enter VIOLA, and Clown with a tabour

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: Save thee, friend, and thy music: dost thou live by
thy tabour?

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: No, sir, I live by the church.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: Art thou a churchman?

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: No such matter, sir: I do live by the church; for
I do live at my house, and my house doth stand by
the church.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: So thou mayst say, the king lies by a beggar, if a
beggar dwell near him; or, the church stands by thy
tabour, if thy tabour stand by the church.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: You have said, sir. To see this age! A sentence is
but a cheveril glove to a good wit: how quickly the
wrong side may be turned outward!

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: Nay, that's certain; they that dally nicely with
words may quickly make them wanton.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: I would, therefore, my sister had had no name, sir.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: Why, man?

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: Why, sir, her name's a word; and to dally with that
word might make my sister wanton. But indeed words
are very rascals since bonds disgraced them.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: Thy reason, man?

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: Troth, sir, I can yield you none without words; and
words are grown so false, I am loath to prove
reason with them.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: I warrant thou art a merry fellow and carest for nothing.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: Not so, sir, I do care for something; but in my
conscience, sir, I do not care for you: if that be
to care for nothing, sir, I would it would make you invisible.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: Art not thou the Lady Olivia's fool?

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: No, indeed, sir; the Lady Olivia has no folly: she
will keep no fool, sir, till she be married; and
fools are as like husbands as pilchards are to
herrings; the husband's the bigger: I am indeed not
her fool, but her corrupter of words.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: I saw thee late at the Count Orsino's.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: Foolery, sir, does walk about the orb like the sun,
it shines every where. I would be sorry, sir, but
the fool should be as oft with your master as with
my mistress: I think I saw your wisdom there.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: Nay, an thou pass upon me, I'll no more with thee.
Hold, there's expenses for thee.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: Now Jove, in his next commodity of hair, send thee a beard!

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: By my troth, I'll tell thee, I am almost sick for
one;
though I would not have it grow on my chin. Is thy
lady within?

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: Would not a pair of these have bred, sir?

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: Yes, being kept together and put to use.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: I would play Lord Pandarus of Phrygia, sir, to bring
a Cressida to this Troilus.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: I understand you, sir; 'tis well begged.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: The matter, I hope, is not great, sir, begging but
a beggar: Cressida was a beggar. My lady is
within, sir. I will construe to them whence you
come; who you are and what you would are out of my
welkin, I might say 'element,' but the word is over-worn.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: This fellow is wise enough to play the fool;
And to do that well craves a kind of wit:
He must observe their mood on whom he jests,
The quality of persons, and the time,
And, like the haggard, cheque at every feather
That comes before his eye. This is a practise
As full of labour as a wise man's art
For folly that he wisely shows is fit;
But wise men, folly-fall'n, quite taint their wit.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH, and SIR ANDREW

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Save you, gentleman.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: And you, sir.

speech.speaker: SIR ANDREW
speech.line: Dieu vous garde, monsieur.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: Et vous aussi; votre serviteur.

speech.speaker: SIR ANDREW
speech.line: I hope, sir, you are; and I am yours.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Will you encounter the house? my niece is desirous
you should enter, if your trade be to her.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: I am bound to your niece, sir; I mean, she is the
list of my voyage.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Taste your legs, sir; put them to motion.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: My legs do better understand me, sir, than I
understand what you mean by bidding me taste my legs.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: I mean, to go, sir, to enter.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: I will answer you with gait and entrance. But we
are prevented.
Most excellent accomplished lady, the heavens rain
odours on you!

speech.speaker: SIR ANDREW
speech.line: That youth's a rare courtier: 'Rain odours;' well.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: My matter hath no voice, to your own most pregnant
and vouchsafed ear.

speech.speaker: SIR ANDREW
speech.line: 'Odours,' 'pregnant' and 'vouchsafed:' I'll get 'em
all three all ready.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: Let the garden door be shut, and leave me to my hearing.
speech.stagedir: Exeunt SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and MARIA
speech.line: Give me your hand, sir.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: My duty, madam, and most humble service.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: What is your name?

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: Cesario is your servant's name, fair princess.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: My servant, sir! 'Twas never merry world
Since lowly feigning was call'd compliment:
You're servant to the Count Orsino, youth.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: And he is yours, and his must needs be yours:
Your servant's servant is your servant, madam.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: For him, I think not on him: for his thoughts,
Would they were blanks, rather than fill'd with me!

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: Madam, I come to whet your gentle thoughts
On his behalf.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: O, by your leave, I pray you,
I bade you never speak again of him:
But, would you undertake another suit,
I had rather hear you to solicit that
Than music from the spheres.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: Dear lady,--

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: Give me leave, beseech you. I did send,
After the last enchantment you did here,
A ring in chase of you: so did I abuse
Myself, my servant and, I fear me, you:
Under your hard construction must I sit,
To force that on you, in a shameful cunning,
Which you knew none of yours: what might you think?
Have you not set mine honour at the stake
And baited it with all the unmuzzled thoughts
That tyrannous heart can think? To one of your receiving
Enough is shown: a cypress, not a bosom,
Hideth my heart. So, let me hear you speak.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: I pity you.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: That's a degree to love.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: No, not a grize; for 'tis a vulgar proof,
That very oft we pity enemies.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: Why, then, methinks 'tis time to smile again.
O, world, how apt the poor are to be proud!
If one should be a prey, how much the better
To fall before the lion than the wolf!
The clock upbraids me with the waste of time.
Be not afraid, good youth, I will not have you:
And yet, when wit and youth is come to harvest,
Your were is alike to reap a proper man:
There lies your way, due west.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: Then westward-ho! Grace and good disposition
Attend your ladyship!
You'll nothing, madam, to my lord by me?

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: Stay:
I prithee, tell me what thou thinkest of me.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: That you do think you are not what you are.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: If I think so, I think the same of you.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: Then think you right: I am not what I am.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: I would you were as I would have you be!

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: Would it be better, madam, than I am?
I wish it might, for now I am your fool.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: O, what a deal of scorn looks beautiful
In the contempt and anger of his lip!
A murderous guilt shows not itself more soon
Than love that would seem hid: love's night is noon.
Cesario, by the roses of the spring,
By maidhood, honour, truth and every thing,
I love thee so, that, maugre all thy pride,
Nor wit nor reason can my passion hide.
Do not extort thy reasons from this clause,
For that I woo, thou therefore hast no cause,
But rather reason thus with reason fetter,
Love sought is good, but given unsought better.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: By innocence I swear, and by my youth
I have one heart, one bosom and one truth,
And that no woman has; nor never none
Shall mistress be of it, save I alone.
And so adieu, good madam: never more
Will I my master's tears to you deplore.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: Yet come again; for thou perhaps mayst move
That heart, which now abhors, to like his love.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN

speech.speaker: SIR ANDREW
speech.line: No, faith, I'll not stay a jot longer.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Thy reason, dear venom, give thy reason.

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: You must needs yield your reason, Sir Andrew.

speech.speaker: SIR ANDREW
speech.line: Marry, I saw your niece do more favours to the
count's serving-man than ever she bestowed upon me;
I saw't i' the orchard.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Did she see thee the while, old boy? tell me that.

speech.speaker: SIR ANDREW
speech.line: As plain as I see you now.

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: This was a great argument of love in her toward you.

speech.speaker: SIR ANDREW
speech.line: 'Slight, will you make an ass o' me?

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: I will prove it legitimate, sir, upon the oaths of
judgment and reason.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: And they have been grand-jury-men since before Noah
was a sailor.

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: She did show favour to the youth in your sight only
to exasperate you, to awake your dormouse valour, to
put fire in your heart and brimstone in your liver.
You should then have accosted her; and with some
excellent jests, fire-new from the mint, you should
have banged the youth into dumbness. This was
looked for at your hand, and this was balked: the
double gilt of this opportunity you let time wash
off, and you are now sailed into the north of my
lady's opinion; where you will hang like an icicle
on a Dutchman's beard, unless you do redeem it by
some laudable attempt either of valour or policy.

speech.speaker: SIR ANDREW
speech.line: An't be any way, it must be with valour; for policy
I hate: I had as lief be a Brownist as a
politician.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Why, then, build me thy fortunes upon the basis of
valour. Challenge me the count's youth to fight
with him; hurt him in eleven places: my niece shall
take note of it; and assure thyself, there is no
love-broker in the world can more prevail in man's
commendation with woman than report of valour.

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: There is no way but this, Sir Andrew.

speech.speaker: SIR ANDREW
speech.line: Will either of you bear me a challenge to him?

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Go, write it in a martial hand; be curst and brief;
it is no matter how witty, so it be eloquent and fun
of invention: taunt him with the licence of ink:
if thou thou'st him some thrice, it shall not be
amiss; and as many lies as will lie in thy sheet of
paper, although the sheet were big enough for the
bed of Ware in England, set 'em down: go, about it.
Let there be gall enough in thy ink, though thou
write with a goose-pen, no matter: about it.

speech.speaker: SIR ANDREW
speech.line: Where shall I find you?

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: We'll call thee at the cubiculo: go.

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: This is a dear manikin to you, Sir Toby.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: I have been dear to him, lad, some two thousand
strong, or so.

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: We shall have a rare letter from him: but you'll
not deliver't?

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Never trust me, then; and by all means stir on the
youth to an answer. I think oxen and wainropes
cannot hale them together. For Andrew, if he were
opened, and you find so much blood in his liver as
will clog the foot of a flea, I'll eat the rest of
the anatomy.

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: And his opposite, the youth, bears in his visage no
great presage of cruelty.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Look, where the youngest wren of nine comes.

speech.speaker: MARIA
speech.line: If you desire the spleen, and will laugh yourself
into stitches, follow me. Yond gull Malvolio is
turned heathen, a very renegado; for there is no
Christian, that means to be saved by believing
rightly, can ever believe such impossible passages
of grossness. He's in yellow stockings.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: And cross-gartered?

speech.speaker: MARIA
speech.line: Most villanously; like a pedant that keeps a school
i' the church. I have dogged him, like his
murderer. He does obey every point of the letter
that I dropped to betray him: he does smile his
face into more lines than is in the new map with the
augmentation of the Indies: you have not seen such
a thing as 'tis. I can hardly forbear hurling things
at him. I know my lady will strike him: if she do,
he'll smile and take't for a great favour.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Come, bring us, bring us where he is.

speech.speaker: SEBASTIAN
speech.line: I would not by my will have troubled you;
But, since you make your pleasure of your pains,
I will no further chide you.

speech.speaker: ANTONIO
speech.line: I could not stay behind you: my desire,
More sharp than filed steel, did spur me forth;
And not all love to see you, though so much
As might have drawn one to a longer voyage,
But jealousy what might befall your travel,
Being skilless in these parts; which to a stranger,
Unguided and unfriended, often prove
Rough and unhospitable: my willing love,
The rather by these arguments of fear,
Set forth in your pursuit.

speech.speaker: SEBASTIAN
speech.line: My kind Antonio,
I can no other answer make but thanks,
And thanks; and ever oft good turns
Are shuffled off with such uncurrent pay:
But, were my worth as is my conscience firm,
You should find better dealing. What's to do?
Shall we go see the reliques of this town?

speech.speaker: ANTONIO
speech.line: To-morrow, sir: best first go see your lodging.

speech.speaker: SEBASTIAN
speech.line: I am not weary, and 'tis long to night:
I pray you, let us satisfy our eyes
With the memorials and the things of fame
That do renown this city.

speech.speaker: ANTONIO
speech.line: Would you'ld pardon me;
I do not without danger walk these streets:
Once, in a sea-fight, 'gainst the count his galleys
I did some service; of such note indeed,
That were I ta'en here it would scarce be answer'd.

speech.speaker: SEBASTIAN
speech.line: Belike you slew great number of his people.

speech.speaker: ANTONIO
speech.line: The offence is not of such a bloody nature;
Albeit the quality of the time and quarrel
Might well have given us bloody argument.
It might have since been answer'd in repaying
What we took from them; which, for traffic's sake,
Most of our city did: only myself stood out;
For which, if I be lapsed in this place,
I shall pay dear.

speech.speaker: SEBASTIAN
speech.line: Do not then walk too open.

speech.speaker: ANTONIO
speech.line: It doth not fit me. Hold, sir, here's my purse.
In the south suburbs, at the Elephant,
Is best to lodge: I will bespeak our diet,
Whiles you beguile the time and feed your knowledge
With viewing of the town: there shall you have me.

speech.speaker: SEBASTIAN
speech.line: Why I your purse?

speech.speaker: ANTONIO
speech.line: Haply your eye shall light upon some toy
You have desire to purchase; and your store,
I think, is not for idle markets, sir.

speech.speaker: SEBASTIAN
speech.line: I'll be your purse-bearer and leave you
For an hour.

speech.speaker: ANTONIO
speech.line: To the Elephant.

speech.speaker: SEBASTIAN
speech.line: I do remember.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: I have sent after him: he says he'll come;
How shall I feast him? what bestow of him?
For youth is bought more oft than begg'd or borrow'd.
I speak too loud.
Where is Malvolio? he is sad and civil,
And suits well for a servant with my fortunes:
Where is Malvolio?

speech.speaker: MARIA
speech.line: He's coming, madam; but in very strange manner. He
is, sure, possessed, madam.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: Why, what's the matter? does he rave?

speech.speaker: MARIA
speech.line: No. madam, he does nothing but smile: your
ladyship were best to have some guard about you, if
he come; for, sure, the man is tainted in's wits.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: Go call him hither.
I am as mad as he,
If sad and merry madness equal be.
How now, Malvolio!

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: Sweet lady, ho, ho.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: Smilest thou?
I sent for thee upon a sad occasion.

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: Sad, lady! I could be sad: this does make some
obstruction in the blood, this cross-gartering; but
what of that? if it please the eye of one, it is
with me as the very true sonnet is, 'Please one, and
please all.'

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: Why, how dost thou, man? what is the matter with thee?

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: Not black in my mind, though yellow in my legs. It
did come to his hands, and commands shall be
executed: I think we do know the sweet Roman hand.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: Wilt thou go to bed, Malvolio?

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: To bed! ay, sweet-heart, and I'll come to thee.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: God comfort thee! Why dost thou smile so and kiss
thy hand so oft?

speech.speaker: MARIA
speech.line: How do you, Malvolio?

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: At your request! yes; nightingales answer daws.

speech.speaker: MARIA
speech.line: Why appear you with this ridiculous boldness before my lady?

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: 'Be not afraid of greatness:' 'twas well writ.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: What meanest thou by that, Malvolio?

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: 'Some are born great,'--

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: Ha!

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: 'Some achieve greatness,'--

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: What sayest thou?

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: 'And some have greatness thrust upon them.'

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: Heaven restore thee!

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: 'Remember who commended thy yellow stockings,'--

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: Thy yellow stockings!

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: 'And wished to see thee cross-gartered.'

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: Cross-gartered!

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: 'Go to thou art made, if thou desirest to be so;'--

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: Am I made?

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: 'If not, let me see thee a servant still.'

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: Why, this is very midsummer madness.

speech.speaker: Servant
speech.line: Madam, the young gentleman of the Count Orsino's is
returned: I could hardly entreat him back: he
attends your ladyship's pleasure.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: I'll come to him.
Good Maria, let this fellow be looked to. Where's
my cousin Toby? Let some of my people have a special
care of him: I would not have him miscarry for the
half of my dowry.

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: O, ho! do you come near me now? no worse man than
Sir Toby to look to me! This concurs directly with
the letter: she sends him on purpose, that I may
appear stubborn to him; for she incites me to that
in the letter. 'Cast thy humble slough,' says she;
'be opposite with a kinsman, surly with servants;
let thy tongue tang with arguments of state; put
thyself into the trick of singularity;' and
consequently sets down the manner how; as, a sad
face, a reverend carriage, a slow tongue, in the
habit of some sir of note, and so forth. I have
limed her; but it is Jove's doing, and Jove make me
thankful! And when she went away now, 'Let this
fellow be looked to:' fellow! not Malvolio, nor
after my degree, but fellow. Why, every thing
adheres together, that no dram of a scruple, no
scruple of a scruple, no obstacle, no incredulous
or unsafe circumstance--What can be said? Nothing
that can be can come between me and the full
prospect of my hopes. Well, Jove, not I, is the
doer of this, and he is to be thanked.

scene-body.stagedir: Re-enter MARIA, with SIR TOBY BELCH and FABIAN

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Which way is he, in the name of sanctity? If all
the devils of hell be drawn in little, and Legion
himself possessed him, yet I'll speak to him.

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: Here he is, here he is. How is't with you, sir?
how is't with you, man?

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: Go off; I discard you: let me enjoy my private: go
off.

speech.speaker: MARIA
speech.line: Lo, how hollow the fiend speaks within him! did not
I tell you? Sir Toby, my lady prays you to have a
care of him.

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: Ah, ha! does she so?

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Go to, go to; peace, peace; we must deal gently
with him: let me alone. How do you, Malvolio? how
is't with you? What, man! defy the devil:
consider, he's an enemy to mankind.

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: Do you know what you say?

speech.speaker: MARIA
speech.line: La you, an you speak ill of the devil, how he takes
it at heart! Pray God, he be not bewitched!

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: Carry his water to the wise woman.

speech.speaker: MARIA
speech.line: Marry, and it shall be done to-morrow morning, if I
live. My lady would not lose him for more than I'll say.

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: How now, mistress!

speech.speaker: MARIA
speech.line: O Lord!

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Prithee, hold thy peace; this is not the way: do
you not see you move him? let me alone with him.

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: No way but gentleness; gently, gently: the fiend is
rough, and will not be roughly used.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Why, how now, my bawcock! how dost thou, chuck?

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: Sir!

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Ay, Biddy, come with me. What, man! 'tis not for
gravity to play at cherry-pit with Satan: hang
him, foul collier!

speech.speaker: MARIA
speech.line: Get him to say his prayers, good Sir Toby, get him to pray.

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: My prayers, minx!

speech.speaker: MARIA
speech.line: No, I warrant you, he will not hear of godliness.

speech.speaker: MALVOLIO
speech.line: Go, hang yourselves all! you are idle shallow
things: I am not of your element: you shall know
more hereafter.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Is't possible?

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: If this were played upon a stage now, I could
condemn it as an improbable fiction.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: His very genius hath taken the infection of the device, man.

speech.speaker: MARIA
speech.line: Nay, pursue him now, lest the device take air and taint.

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: Why, we shall make him mad indeed.

speech.speaker: MARIA
speech.line: The house will be the quieter.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Come, we'll have him in a dark room and bound. My
niece is already in the belief that he's mad: we
may carry it thus, for our pleasure and his penance,
till our very pastime, tired out of breath, prompt
us to have mercy on him: at which time we will
bring the device to the bar and crown thee for a
finder of madmen. But see, but see.

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: More matter for a May morning.

speech.speaker: SIR ANDREW
speech.line: Here's the challenge, read it: warrant there's
vinegar and pepper in't.

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: Is't so saucy?

speech.speaker: SIR ANDREW
speech.line: Ay, is't, I warrant him: do but read.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Give me.
'Youth, whatsoever thou art, thou art but a scurvy fellow.'

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: Good, and valiant.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Reads 'Wonder not, nor admire not in thy mind,
why I do call thee so, for I will show thee no reason for't.'

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: A good note; that keeps you from the blow of the law.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Reads 'Thou comest to the lady Olivia, and in my
sight she uses thee kindly: but thou liest in thy
throat; that is not the matter I challenge thee for.'

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: Very brief, and to exceeding good sense--less.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Reads 'I will waylay thee going home; where if it
be thy chance to kill me,'--

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: Good.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Reads 'Thou killest me like a rogue and a villain.'

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: Still you keep o' the windy side of the law: good.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Reads 'Fare thee well; and God have mercy upon
one of our souls! He may have mercy upon mine; but
my hope is better, and so look to thyself. Thy
friend, as thou usest him, and thy sworn enemy,
ANDREW AGUECHEEK.
If this letter move him not, his legs cannot:
I'll give't him.

speech.speaker: MARIA
speech.line: You may have very fit occasion for't: he is now in
some commerce with my lady, and will by and by depart.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Go, Sir Andrew: scout me for him at the corner the
orchard like a bum-baily: so soon as ever thou seest
him, draw; and, as thou drawest swear horrible; for
it comes to pass oft that a terrible oath, with a
swaggering accent sharply twanged off, gives manhood
more approbation than ever proof itself would have
earned him. Away!

speech.speaker: SIR ANDREW
speech.line: Nay, let me alone for swearing.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Now will not I deliver his letter: for the behavior
of the young gentleman gives him out to be of good
capacity and breeding; his employment between his
lord and my niece confirms no less: therefore this
letter, being so excellently ignorant, will breed no
terror in the youth: he will find it comes from a
clodpole. But, sir, I will deliver his challenge by
word of mouth; set upon Aguecheek a notable report
of valour; and drive the gentleman, as I know his
youth will aptly receive it, into a most hideous
opinion of his rage, skill, fury and impetuosity.
This will so fright them both that they will kill
one another by the look, like cockatrices.

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: Here he comes with your niece: give them way till
he take leave, and presently after him.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: I will meditate the while upon some horrid message
for a challenge.

scene-body.stagedir: Exeunt SIR TOBY BELCH, FABIAN, and MARIA

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: I have said too much unto a heart of stone
And laid mine honour too unchary out:
There's something in me that reproves my fault;
But such a headstrong potent fault it is,
That it but mocks reproof.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: With the same 'havior that your passion bears
Goes on my master's grief.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: Here, wear this jewel for me, 'tis my picture;
Refuse it not; it hath no tongue to vex you;
And I beseech you come again to-morrow.
What shall you ask of me that I'll deny,
That honour saved may upon asking give?

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: Nothing but this; your true love for my master.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: How with mine honour may I give him that
Which I have given to you?

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: I will acquit you.

speech.speaker: OLIVIA
speech.line: Well, come again to-morrow: fare thee well:
A fiend like thee might bear my soul to hell.

scene-body.stagedir: Re-enter SIR TOBY BELCH and FABIAN

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Gentleman, God save thee.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: And you, sir.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: That defence thou hast, betake thee to't: of what
nature the wrongs are thou hast done him, I know
not; but thy intercepter, full of despite, bloody as
the hunter, attends thee at the orchard-end:
dismount thy tuck, be yare in thy preparation, for
thy assailant is quick, skilful and deadly.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: You mistake, sir; I am sure no man hath any quarrel
to me: my remembrance is very free and clear from
any image of offence done to any man.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: You'll find it otherwise, I assure you: therefore,
if you hold your life at any price, betake you to
your guard; for your opposite hath in him what
youth, strength, skill and wrath can furnish man withal.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: I pray you, sir, what is he?

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: He is knight, dubbed with unhatched rapier and on
carpet consideration; but he is a devil in private
brawl: souls and bodies hath he divorced three; and
his incensement at this moment is so implacable,
that satisfaction can be none but by pangs of death
and sepulchre. Hob, nob, is his word; give't or take't.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: I will return again into the house and desire some
conduct of the lady. I am no fighter. I have heard
of some kind of men that put quarrels purposely on
others, to taste their valour: belike this is a man
of that quirk.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Sir, no; his indignation derives itself out of a
very competent injury: therefore, get you on and
give him his desire. Back you shall not to the
house, unless you undertake that with me which with
as much safety you might answer him: therefore, on,
or strip your sword stark naked; for meddle you
must, that's certain, or forswear to wear iron about you.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: This is as uncivil as strange. I beseech you, do me
this courteous office, as to know of the knight what
my offence to him is: it is something of my
negligence, nothing of my purpose.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: I will do so. Signior Fabian, stay you by this
gentleman till my return.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: Pray you, sir, do you know of this matter?

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: I know the knight is incensed against you, even to a
mortal arbitrement; but nothing of the circumstance more.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: I beseech you, what manner of man is he?

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: Nothing of that wonderful promise, to read him by
his form, as you are like to find him in the proof
of his valour. He is, indeed, sir, the most skilful,
bloody and fatal opposite that you could possibly
have found in any part of Illyria. Will you walk
towards him? I will make your peace with him if I
can.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: I shall be much bound to you for't: I am one that
had rather go with sir priest than sir knight: I
care not who knows so much of my mettle.

scene-body.stagedir: Re-enter SIR TOBY BELCH, with SIR ANDREW

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Why, man, he's a very devil; I have not seen such a
firago. I had a pass with him, rapier, scabbard and
all, and he gives me the stuck in with such a mortal
motion, that it is inevitable; and on the answer, he
pays you as surely as your feet hit the ground they
step on. They say he has been fencer to the Sophy.

speech.speaker: SIR ANDREW
speech.line: Pox on't, I'll not meddle with him.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Ay, but he will not now be pacified: Fabian can
scarce hold him yonder.

speech.speaker: SIR ANDREW
speech.line: Plague on't, an I thought he had been valiant and so
cunning in fence, I'ld have seen him damned ere I'ld
have challenged him. Let him let the matter slip,
and I'll give him my horse, grey Capilet.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: I'll make the motion: stand here, make a good show
on't: this shall end without the perdition of souls.
Marry, I'll ride your horse as well as I ride you.
I have his horse to take up the quarrel:
I have persuaded him the youth's a devil.

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: He is as horribly conceited of him; and pants and
looks pale, as if a bear were at his heels.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: To VIOLA There's no remedy, sir; he will fight
with you for's oath sake: marry, he hath better
bethought him of his quarrel, and he finds that now
scarce to be worth talking of: therefore draw, for
the supportance of his vow; he protests he will not hurt you.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: Aside Pray God defend me! A little thing would
make me tell them how much I lack of a man.

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: Give ground, if you see him furious.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Come, Sir Andrew, there's no remedy; the gentleman
will, for his honour's sake, have one bout with you;
he cannot by the duello avoid it: but he has
promised me, as he is a gentleman and a soldier, he
will not hurt you. Come on; to't.

speech.speaker: SIR ANDREW
speech.line: Pray God, he keep his oath!

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: I do assure you, 'tis against my will.

speech.speaker: ANTONIO
speech.line: Put up your sword. If this young gentleman
Have done offence, I take the fault on me:
If you offend him, I for him defy you.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: You, sir! why, what are you?

speech.speaker: ANTONIO
speech.line: One, sir, that for his love dares yet do more
Than you have heard him brag to you he will.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Nay, if you be an undertaker, I am for you.

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: O good Sir Toby, hold! here come the officers.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: I'll be with you anon.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: Pray, sir, put your sword up, if you please.

speech.speaker: SIR ANDREW
speech.line: Marry, will I, sir; and, for that I promised you,
I'll be as good as my word: he will bear you easily
and reins well.

speech.speaker: First Officer
speech.line: This is the man; do thy office.

speech.speaker: Second Officer
speech.line: Antonio, I arrest thee at the suit of Count Orsino.

speech.speaker: ANTONIO
speech.line: You do mistake me, sir.

speech.speaker: First Officer
speech.line: No, sir, no jot; I know your favour well,
Though now you have no sea-cap on your head.
Take him away: he knows I know him well.

speech.speaker: ANTONIO
speech.line: I must obey.
This comes with seeking you:
But there's no remedy; I shall answer it.
What will you do, now my necessity
Makes me to ask you for my purse? It grieves me
Much more for what I cannot do for you
Than what befalls myself. You stand amazed;
But be of comfort.

speech.speaker: Second Officer
speech.line: Come, sir, away.

speech.speaker: ANTONIO
speech.line: I must entreat of you some of that money.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: What money, sir?
For the fair kindness you have show'd me here,
And, part, being prompted by your present trouble,
Out of my lean and low ability
I'll lend you something: my having is not much;
I'll make division of my present with you:
Hold, there's half my coffer.

speech.speaker: ANTONIO
speech.line: Will you deny me now?
Is't possible that my deserts to you
Can lack persuasion? Do not tempt my misery,
Lest that it make me so unsound a man
As to upbraid you with those kindnesses
That I have done for you.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: I know of none;
Nor know I you by voice or any feature:
I hate ingratitude more in a man
Than lying, vainness, babbling, drunkenness,
Or any taint of vice whose strong corruption
Inhabits our frail blood.

speech.speaker: ANTONIO
speech.line: O heavens themselves!

speech.speaker: Second Officer
speech.line: Come, sir, I pray you, go.

speech.speaker: ANTONIO
speech.line: Let me speak a little. This youth that you see here
I snatch'd one half out of the jaws of death,
Relieved him with such sanctity of love,
And to his image, which methought did promise
Most venerable worth, did I devotion.

speech.speaker: First Officer
speech.line: What's that to us? The time goes by: away!

speech.speaker: ANTONIO
speech.line: But O how vile an idol proves this god
Thou hast, Sebastian, done good feature shame.
In nature there's no blemish but the mind;
None can be call'd deform'd but the unkind:
Virtue is beauty, but the beauteous evil
Are empty trunks o'erflourish'd by the devil.

speech.speaker: First Officer
speech.line: The man grows mad: away with him! Come, come, sir.

speech.speaker: ANTONIO
speech.line: Lead me on.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: Methinks his words do from such passion fly,
That he believes himself: so do not I.
Prove true, imagination, O, prove true,
That I, dear brother, be now ta'en for you!

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Come hither, knight; come hither, Fabian: we'll
whisper o'er a couplet or two of most sage saws.

speech.speaker: VIOLA
speech.line: He named Sebastian: I my brother know
Yet living in my glass; even such and so
In favour was my brother, and he went
Still in this fashion, colour, ornament,
For him I imitate: O, if it prove,
Tempests are kind and salt waves fresh in love.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: A very dishonest paltry boy, and more a coward than
a hare: his dishonesty appears in leaving his
friend here in necessity and denying him; and for
his cowardship, ask Fabian.

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: A coward, a most devout coward, religious in it.

speech.speaker: SIR ANDREW
speech.line: 'Slid, I'll after him again and beat him.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: Do; cuff him soundly, but never draw thy sword.

speech.speaker: SIR ANDREW
speech.line: An I do not,--

speech.speaker: FABIAN
speech.line: Come, let's see the event.

speech.speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
speech.line: I dare lay any money 'twill be nothing yet.
